comments:
Eclipse takes the load on my machine to 100% after I save a file, or after a 
full rebuild is invoked.  I have just upgraded my JVM to 1.4.2 from 1.4.1.  
The environment works just fine, and I have changed the default behavior in 
the Java Compiler to be 1.4.  Because of this, I have to shutdown Eclipse and 
restart it after a few file edits, or the machine becomes somewhat unusable, 
since Eclipse is utilizing 98%->100% of the CPU.

In the .metadata\.log file I have the following :

!SESSION Oct 10, 2003 13:08:40.957 ---------------------------------------------
java.version=1.4.2_01
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US
Command-line arguments: -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86 -install 
file:D:/Tools/eclipse/
!ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.debug 4 120 Oct 10, 2003 13:08:40.957
!MESSAGE Internal error logged from JDI Debug: 
!STACK 0
org.eclipse.jdi.TimeoutException
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.PacketReceiveManager.getReply
(PacketReceiveManager.java:149)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.PacketReceiveManager.getReply
(PacketReceiveManager.java:158)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.MirrorImpl.requestVM(MirrorImpl.java:173)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.MirrorImpl.requestVM(MirrorImpl.java:191)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.MirrorImpl.requestVM(MirrorImpl.java:206)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.ObjectReferenceImpl.isCollected
(ObjectReferenceImpl.java:388)
	at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIDebugTarget$ThreadStartHandler.hand
leEvent(JDIDebugTarget.java:1567)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.EventDispatcher.dispatch
(EventDispatcher.java:135)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.EventDispatcher.run
(EventDispatcher.java:211)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534)

Please do the following:

- try running with java.exe instead of javaw.exe
- when the CPU is at 100%, hit Ctrl+Break in the console to produce a stack dump
- attach the stack dump to this report (use "Create new attachment" button near
the top of the page in bugzilla).

Are you saying that it stays at 100% permanently until you quit Eclipse, or only
temporarily?

Yes, the CPU goes to 100% and does not come back until I shut down Eclipse. 
Eclipse is "responsive" (i.e. I can edit and the like) but the machine in 
general is sluggish because of the high load.

We have been unable to reproduce this problem. If you still experience this
problem in the latest builds and are able to provide us steps to replicate it,
then please re-open this bug report.
